raw_text:
Singer Knight backs anti-gun song
 
 R&B star Beverley Knight said she sang on an anti-gun single after being "haunted" by the fatal 2003 shooting of two teenage girls in Birmingham.
 
 Knight and drum 'n' bass star Roni Size have released No More in a bid to reduce gun use among young people. She said she was "horrified" by the deaths of Charlene Ellis, 18, and Letisha Shakespeare, 17. Size, whose New Forms album won the 1997 Mercury Music Prize, said gun use was "nothing to be glamorised".
 
 There were more than 10,500 firearms offences and 70 gun crime deaths in England and Wales between June 2003 and 2004, according to Home Office figures. Knight said the scale of the problem became clear to her after the 2003 shootings in Aston, near Knight's Birmingham home.
 
 "It haunted me to be honest, it haunted my sleep," she said. Size became involved after two friends, Donna Small and Asha Jama, were shot in his Bristol hometown in October. Jama, 25, lost her sight in one eye while 22-year-old Small suffered serious head injuries. Size said he collaborated on the single, which was released on Monday, because he has "a bird's eye view of what's going on". "Over the last 10 years, I have seen a lot of things happen and it is nothing to be glamorised, it really isn't," he said.
llama3.2:1b: Beverley Knight sang an anti-gun song after being haunted by the 2003 Birmingham shootings. Roni Size released the song "No More" as part of his campaign to reduce gun use among young people in England and Wales.
llama3.2:3b: Beverley Knight released an anti-gun single with Roni Size following fatal shootings in Birmingham and Bristol that left two teenagers disabled and another dead.
gemma2:2b: R&B star Beverley Knight released an anti-gun song called "No More" with drum 'n' bass artist Roni Size. The single aims to reduce gun use among young people after a series of shootings in Birmingham haunted the singer.  Size, who has witnessed gun violence in his own community, collaborated on the song because he believes gun violence is a serious issue that should not be glamourized.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The singer Beverley Knight sang a song on her album No More that night, and she expressed horror at seeing a tragic shooting. The gun crime rate in England and Wales was 10,500 firearms offences and 70 deaths from gun-related incidents between June 2003 and October 2004, according to Home Office figures. Size became involved after his friends were shot in Bristol but he collaborated with Knight on a song called No More that night because he has "a bird's eye view of what's going on".
qwen2.5:1.5b: Beverley Knight, R&B singer, backed by Roni Size for an anti-gun song released in June after being "haunted" by the 2003 shooting deaths of Charlene Ellis and Letisha Shakespeare in Birmingham. The single promotes reducing gun use among young people to prevent future tragedies.
qwen2.5:3b: Singer Beverley Knight collaborated with Roni Size on an anti-gun single called "No More" after being haunted by the deaths of two teenage girls in Birmingham in 2003. The song aims to reduce gun use among young people. Knight, who was "horrified" by the killings of Charlene Ellis and Letisha Shakespeare, participated due to the shootings near her home haunting her. There were over 10,500 firearms offenses and 70 gun-related deaths in England and Wales from June 2003 to 2004. Size contributed because he has seen many such incidents firsthand and emphasized that gun use should not be glamorized.

She expressed being "horrified" by their deaths and how it impacted her sleep. Size, whose friends Donna Small and Asha Jama were shot in his Bristol hometown, joined the project due to his firsthand experience of gun violence over the past decade. He emphasized that such incidents should not be glamorized. The single was released in 2004 amid a broader trend of firearms offenses and gun crime deaths in England and Wales, with over 10,500 such cases reported between June 2003 and 2004, according to Home Office figures.
